title: 110_s724
content: The Act may be cited as the "Little Shell Tribe of Chippewa Indians Restoration Act of 2007". Congress finds that the Little Shell Tribe of Chippewa Indians is a political successor to signatories of the Pembina Treaty of 1863, ceding land in North Dakota to the United States. The Tribe, along with other Chippewa tribes, has been recognized by the Federal Government. Members of the Little Shell Tribe have lived in Montana for over 100 years, and the Tribe has a history of petitioning in the 1930s and 1940s. In the 1930s and 1940s, the Little Shell Tribe petitioned the Federal Government for reorganization under the Indian Reorganization Act. Federal agents and the Commissioner of Indian Affairs acknowledged the Tribe's eligibility for trust land, but due to lack of funding during the Depression, the Bureau of Indian Affairs couldn't purchase land for the Tribe. The Little Shell Tribe, despite the lack of funding from the Federal Government, continued to exist as a separate community with clear political leadership. They, along with other tribes, filed lawsuits under the Indian Claims Commission Act to seek compensation for land ceded to the United States. The Little Shell Tribe sought compensation for land ceded under treaties with the United States in 1863 and 1892. They received awards in 1971 and 1982. In 1978, the Tribe petitioned for Federal recognition, which is still pending. The Tribe has had continuous dealings with the Federal Government, the State of Montana, and other recognized Indian tribes since the 1930s. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "member" refers to an individual enrolled in the Tribe pursuant to section 7. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribe" refers to the Little Shell Tribe of Chippewa Indians of Montana. Federal recognition is extended to the Tribe, and all Federal laws applicable to Indians and Indian tribes, including the Indian Reorganization Act, shall apply to the Tribe and its members. Beginning on the date of enactment of this Act, the Tribe and its members will be eligible for all services and benefits provided by the United States to Indians and federally recognized Indian tribes, regardless of the existence of a reservation or the location of residence. The service area for the delivery of services and benefits to members will include Blaine, Cascade, Glacier, and Hill Counties in Montana. SEC. 6. REAFFIRMATION OF RIGHTS. This Act does not diminish any existing rights or privileges of the Tribe or its members. Claims of the Tribe to enforce any wrongfully denied rights are preserved. SEC. 7. MEMBERSHIP ROLL. SEC. 7. MEMBERSHIP ROLL. The Tribe must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 18 months of the Act's enactment, based on qualifications outlined in the Tribe's constitution. The Tribe is responsible for maintaining the membership roll. The Secretary will acquire 200 acres of land for the Tribe's benefit to establish a tribal land base. Additional land may be acquired under the Indian Reorganization Act.
